1401300901|2.0|The book looks promising from its description. The premise is: Dead husband leaves love letters to wife from the beyond in hopes to help her grieve. However, while reading it, I didn't find myself sympathetic with the main character, Holly, even though she'd lost her husband.  <br /> <br />Holly is undescriptive. We know more about her siblings and friends than we ever do about her. All we know is that Holly was married to Gerry (her late husband) and now she pines for him. Every other line in this book reads \\"Holly's life revolved around Gerry\\", or \\"Now life meant nothing to Holly\\". It really makes the book boring! The only moments of entertainment are when she is surrounded by her friends: the stereotypical party girl who finds her soulmate and the wife who's expecting a baby. Of course, Holly feels no joy for her friends because \\"she'll never have Gerry again\\". The whole book reads like this. <br /> <br />We're given no reason to feel sympathetic towards Holly other than the fact that she is a young widow. Apparently, before Gerry died, all she did was sit at home all day, pining for him while he was at work. She refused to learn anything domestic, and just lays in bed all day. (Not to impune on grieving widows-just to say, this is all she does and it's really boring!) <br /> <br />This is an ok book if you're not someone who reads alot, and by that I mean, you probably won't care that the books drags on and on and on over the grief of Holly, the boring widow. For those expecting a literary masterpiece, this isn't it. Ms. Ahern gave it a good try, but unfortunately, the dullness of her main character kills her effort.

B0009HLDFU|1.0|This is one of those Sony CD's that contains \\"XCP\\" spyware.  XCP was written with the intent of concealing its presence and operation from the owner of the computer, and once installed, elements of the software run continuously -- even when no Sony-BMG music CD is in use. It provides no clear uninstallation option.  <br /> <br />Additionally, without notifying users, the software appears to contact a remote machine under your control.  <br /> <br />Sony has shocked and angered people over this issue. Software that deceives the owner of the computer it runs upon and opens that computer up to attacks by third parties may be expected to come from malicious cyber-attacks; it is certainly not expected nor acceptable to be distributed and sold to paying customers by a major music company.  <br /> <br />Sony should temporarily halt manufacturing CDs with XCP and reexamine \\"all aspects\\" of their \\"content protection initiative.\\"  <br /> <br />If Sony truly intends to undo the harm that they have caused, they should immediately and publicly commit to the following measures:  <br /> <br />1) Sony should recall all CDs that contain the XCP and SunnComm MediaMax technology. It must include removing all infected CDs from store shelves as well as halting all online sales of the affected merchandise.  <br /> <br />A recent New York Times article said that well over 2 million infected CDs with the XCP technology are in the marketplace and have yet to be sold.  <br /> <br />2) Sony should remove from all current and future marketing materials statements like that on [...] that say the cloaking software \\"is not malicious and does not compromise security.\\"  <br /> <br />3) Sony should widely publicize the potential security and other risks associated with the XCP and SunnComm MediaMax technology to allow the 2.1 million consumers who have already purchased the CDs to make informed decisions regarding their use of those CDs. The publicity campaign should include, at a minimum, issuing apublic statement describing the risks and listing every Sony CD, DVD or other product that contains XCP or SunnComm MediaMax. The publicity campaign should be advertised in a manner reasonably calculated to reach all consumers who have purchased the products, in all markets where the CDs have been sold.  <br /> <br />4) Sony should cooperate fully with any interested manufacturer of anti-virus, anti-spyware, or similar computer security tools to facilitate the identification and complete removal of XCP and SunnComm MediaMax from the computers of those infected. In particular, Sony should publicly waive any claims it may have for investigation or removal of these tools under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) and any similar laws.  <br /> <br />5) Sony should offer to refund the purchase price of infected CDs or, at the consumer's election, provide a replacement CD that does not contain the XCP or SunnComm technology. For those consumers who choose to retain infected CDs, develop and make widely available a software update that will allow consumers to easily uninstall the technology without losing the ability to play the CD on their computers.  <br /> <br />In addition, consumers should not be required to reveal any personally identifying information to Sony in order to access the update, as Sony is currently requiring.  <br /> <br />6) Sony should compensate consumers for any damage to their computers caused by the infected products, including the time, effort, and expenditure required to remedy the damage or verify that their computer systems or networks were or were not altered or damaged by XCP or SunnComm MediaMax products.  <br /> <br />I'm not buying any more Sony CD's until they do the above! <br />
1559409002|2.0|Carnival of Souls (Herk Harvey, 1962)<br /><br />Herk Harvey's Carnival of Souls is your classic cult-hit B movie; it's terrible, but that it's terrible is half the fun of watching it.<br /><br />The story concerns Mary Henry (stage actress Candace Hilligoss), who is the only survivor of a car full of women who lose control and veer off a bridge during a drag race. Wanting to get away from the scene of the accident and start a new life, she moves to, of all places, Utah to take a job as a church organist. She finds herself, however, plagued with hallucinations, fainting spells, and other such things that make her realize something is very wrong, while finding herself drawn to a long-abandoned carnival on the outskirts of town.<br /><br />In order to really get at the entertainment value of this flick, you have to overlook a lot of things-- most notably, the painfully cheesy overacting. Hilligoss wanders through the film looking like a prototype of Nico (of The Velvet Underground and... fame), while her would-be suitor Sidney Berger (now director of the Houston Shakespeare Festival, so you have to figure the guy's got chops) hops around like a gerbil on benzedrine; Roger Ebert, in his original review, called Berger's character \\"the definitive study of a nerd in lust.\\" The other main thing you have to overlook is the terrible special effects, but one figures the movie was made with a bargain-basement budget. That it manages to evoke anything other than laughs is testament to some real talent lurking beneath all the silliness. **
B000002MFE|5.0|I have read a lot of positive comments about Eric Clapton Unplugged and I enjoyed every one. Good blues all around. Favorie cut:Layla. This is the type of song to listen to a hot humid weekend afternoon with ceiling fans rotating and bottle of wine by your side. AWESOME! Go out and buy it!
0375422889|4.0|Marjane Satrapi, Persepolis 2: The Story of a Return (Pantheon, 2004)<br /><br />Marjane Satrapi's Persepolis took the world by storm a few years ago, first in its native French, then in English. Of course, since the graphic autobiography (\\"graphic\\" in terms of \\"graphic novel,\\" not as in 100 Strokes of the Brush Before Bed) stops when Satrapi is fourteen, you know there has to be more.<br /><br />Persepolis 2: The Story of a Return takes us through Satrapi's adolescence-- her years in Europe, then, as the title promises, a return to Iran during her eighteenth year after a cascade of nasty events (some her fault, some not) that leave her homeless and ill.<br /><br />Where Persepolis is good, its sequel plays on the first book's strengths while more successfully integrating the overarching issues of the never-ending wars in which Iran finds itself. When Satrapi discusses the regime's reasons for using the veils in the book's most important panels, it doesn't seem intrusive at all, despite stopping the action (briefly) and having no use other than imparting sociopolitical values. It's a very rare thing when that works.<br /><br />Persepolis is good stuff; Persepolis 2 is even better. *** 
B000BO0LLS|5.0|\\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\" is by far the best album released this year (to me, anyway).  It marks a tremendous comeback for Miss. Carey (she went from being the laughingstock of the music industry to having the song that spent the most weeks at #1 in this decade, so far at least).  Every song bubbles with excellent production and terrific vocals.  Highlights include the monster hit single, \\"We Belong Together\\" (which y'all have heard a million times on the radio so I don't think I need to describe it), the smooth sexy Kanye-produced \\"Stay The Night\\", which features her greatest vocal performance in years, the slick Snoop Dogg collabo \\"Say Somethin\\", the old school 70's throwback \\"Circles\\", the classy piano ballad \\"I Wish You Knew\\", and the final track, the gospel rouser \\"Fly Like A Bird\\".  The album is by no means perfect (the should've-been-wonderful Nelly collabo \\"To The Floor\\" is surprisingly dull) but on the whole it is a superb disc and unquestionably the best thing Carey's released this millenium.  This re-release comes with four new songs including the big hit \\"Don't Forget About Us\\", the Twista collabo \\"So Lonely\\" and the remix of \\"We Belong Together\\" feautring Jadakiss and Styles P.  It also includes a bonus DVD with four videos and an interview with Miss. Carey. The re-release is a great buy for anyone who missed out on the original edition and also a great stocking-stuffer for a young person just getting into Mariah Carey. <br />Side Note: Shoppers, please ignore the one-star reviews for this item.  The majority of them are written by Madonna and Jennifer Lopez fanatics who have not even heard the album but want to bring Carey down because her success somehow interferes with their respective happiness.  It literally makes me sick to the stomach when I think about all that this woman has been through in the past five years and how there are still cold-hearted people trying to bring her down.  Please do not let these ignorant reviews change your opinion about purchasing the album.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|I have to first admit that I am a long time Madonna fan and typically enjoy her CDs.  This album has met all my expectations and more.  Many listeners will enjoy the fact that the songs flow seamlessly into each other (remember when you used to put on a record and just let it play!).  No skipping is needed with this album.  All the songs have at least one catchy hook that will keep your attention and make you want to dance.  As with most pop songs, the lyrics are pretty basic, but you will be able to (and want to) sing along after a few spins.  The standout tracks on this album are Jump, Get Together, Sorry, Push and Hung Up.  Each song is unique enough to sound fresh and new, but they also summon you back to the 70s and 80s.  Future Lovers, I Love NY, How High and Let It Will Be will also be big in dance clubs. The rest of the tracks take some getting used to, but support the overall theme of the album - dance music with a purpose.

B000025H0Q|2.0|I am a huge fan of Nick Drake but this is my least favorite of his albums and I have rarely listened to it since getting it ten years ago. In fact, I'm glad this wasn't the first disc of his that I purchased or I probably wouldn't have bought any of his other albums. This album is way too overproduced. The best example is \\"At The Chime of a City Clock\\" which starts out strong but is overwhelmed by the riffing saxaphone after each line sung by Nick Drake from the second verse on. The first time I heard \\"Hazey Jane II\\" I couldn't believe it was Nick Drake it was so downright cheesy and dated. The instrumentals on this disc border on easy listening also, which ain't my style. The only songs worth hearing are \\"Northern Sky\\" (one of the most beautiful songs I've ever heard) and \\"Fly\\", although I prefer the home version he recorded at Tanworth in Arden in 1969 to the studio version. It's interesting that John Cale was a guest on this album, but the results overall were subpar compared to the rest of Nick Drake's recorded work. I don't think it's a coincidence that Nick Drake's follow up to \\"Bryter Layter\\" was the extremely sparse \\"Pink Moon\\" album. I think it was a direct reaction to the overproduction that weakened his songs on \\"Bryter Layter\\". \\"Pink Moon\\" benefits from the setting of just Nick Drake and his guitar, while the songs here are marred and dated by the arrangements. I don't understand why anyone would rate this as Nick Drake's best work. While I wouldn't hesitate to recommend Nick Drake's music to anyone, I wouldn't recommend starting here. Try \\"Five Leaves Left\\" or \\"Pink Moon\\" first.

0385338686|2.0|When you settle in with a Sophie Kinsella book, you need to pack away your cynic's hat. Because these books can be a fantastic indulgence, but not if you turn each page with an eye out for the faults.<br /><br />In The Undomestic Goddess, the main character is a tough, successful London attorney. Everything in her life is exaggerated in typical Kinsella style: Her family blows off her birthday, she can't picture a vacuum cleaner bag, she works All The Time.<br /><br />Then, she apparently makes a major mistake. When she realizes its ramifications, she freaks out and flees blindly to the countryside. Then, in typically whacky Kinsella style, she becomes a housekeeper to a nouveau-riche couple.<br /><br />Of course, she learns to do the job well, sneakily handles some legal work for her boss, falls in love, relaxes, becomes more beautiful, and exposes some major corruption back in London.<br /><br />Even if you like this syrupy and silly kind of story, there are some major issues with the premise. Why is it that working women are so often portrayed as colorless, unhappy and unfulfilled? The message that giving up your career for a country life of bread-baking, that just seems to be an old-fashioned, even anti-woman message. I don't want to spoil the fun of the book, but that's a pretty major problem.<br /><br />I also thought Kinsella missed a chance to tie up a lot of loose ends. Even if she'd added a \\"Six Months Later\\" final chapter, she could have told us what happened to her nouveau riche couple's legal tangles, if the lady of the house found a fulfilling volunteer opporunity, and many other tidbits.<br /><br />Kinsella is a delightful writer. Her characters are loopy and self-effacing, if over-the-top. If you can get past the silliness, and the troubling anti-working-woman premise of the plot, this is a funny, joyful read. In fact, I'd say it's one of her best books ever.
